hint.text: Remember that enthalpy is an extensive property.

solution.text:
Use the standard enthalpies of formation to calculate the enthalpy of change for the reaction as follows:
\(\Delta_rH^\circleddash = \sum \Delta_fH^\circleddash_ {products} - \sum \Delta_fH^\circleddash_ {reactants}\)
\(\implies \Delta_rH^\circleddash = ((_{{2*k}}_ \times -393.509) + (_{{3*k}}_ \times -285.83)) - (_{k}_ \times -277.69) = - _{{((2*k*(393.509)) + (3*k*(285.83))) - (k*(277.69))}}_ \frac{kJ}{mol}\)

The unit for \(\Delta_rH^\circleddash\) is \(\frac{kJ}{mol}\), which stands for per mole of reaction. We define the mole of reaction based on how we balance the chemical equation.
